children.name: likely to happen or be true
probably a2
children.definition: probably/ˈprɒbəbliǁˈprɑː-/  when something willprobablyhappen or isprobablytrue:
examples: chắc là
▪ ‘where is she?’ ‘probably in her room.’
▪ we’ll probably be shooting the movie on location in europe.
▪ archaeologists think the temple was probably built in the 3rd century ad.
▪ he wrote dozens of books, but this is probably his best-known novel.

children.name: likely b1
children.definition: likely/ˈlaɪkli/  something that is likely will probably happen or is probably true:
examples: có thể xảy ra ( đạt được, thắng lợi..)
▪ the most likely result is a win for the democrats.
likely to do something: có vẻ như...
▪ the price of petrol is likely to rise again this year.
very likely: rất có thể
▪ the jury is very likely to believe he was in the apartment at the time of the crime.
something seems likely
thứ gì đó dường như có thể
▪ a peace settlement now seems likely.
it is likely (that): có vẻ như là
▪ it is likely that the girl knew her killer.

children.name: probable b2
children.definition: probable/ˈprɒbəbəlǁˈprɑː-/ formallikely to be true or likely to happen:có lẽ
examples: it is/seems probable (that): chắc hẳn là
▪ it seems probable that the election will be held in may.
highly probablewhen something will almost certainly happen
rất có khả năng là
▪ unless the government agrees to further talks, a strike seems highly probable.
probable cause: nguyên nhân chắc chắn
▪ the report states that the probable cause of death was a heart attack.
probable cost/result/outcome etc
chi phí dự toán/kết quả có khả năng...
▪ the project will go ahead, at a probable cost of $2.1 million.

children.name: it looks like u
children.definition: it looks as if/it looks like/ɪt ˈlʊks əz ɪf, ɪt ˈlʊks laɪk/spokensay this when the present situation makes you think that something is likely to happen or likely to be true:
examples: có vẻ như
▪ there aren’t any taxis. it looks as if we’ll have to walk.
▪ ted should be here by now. it looks like he’s been delayed.
it looks like beingbritish
có vẻ như là
▪ from the agenda, it looks like being a long meeting.

children.name: i suppose a2
children.definition: i supposealsoi guessamerican /aɪ səˈpəʊz, aɪ ˈges/spokensay this when you think something is likely to be true or likely to happen:
examples: tôi nghĩ, tôi đoán là
i suppose (that)
▪ there was no reply when i phoned - i suppose she’s still at work.
▪ i suppose that they’ll do some sightseeing while they’re here.
▪ i guess kathy will want to bring her boyfriend.
i suppose so/i guess souse this to answer a question
tôi nghĩ, tôi đoán vậy
▪ ‘is bill coming too?’ ‘i suppose so.’
▪ ‘if you don’t pass the test, will you take it again?’ ‘i guess so.’

children.name: i wouldn’t be surprised a2
children.definition: i wouldn’t be surprised/aɪ ˌwʊdnt biː səʳˈpraɪzd/spokensay this when you know enough about a situation to think that something is likely to happen or be true, especially somethingspecialorunusual:
examples: tôi không ngạc nhiên
i wouldn’t be surprised if
tôi không ngạc nhiên nếu
▪ you know, i wouldn’t be surprised if they decided to get married.
i wouldn’t be surprised to hear/see/find etc that
tôi không ngạc nhiên khi nghe/thấy... rằng
▪ i wouldn’t be surprised to hear that she’d left that job by now.

children.name: strong possibility b1
children.definition: be a strong possibility/biː ə ˌstrɒŋ pɒsˈbɪltiǁ-ˌstrɔːŋ pɑː-/  to be very likely:có khả năng
examples: ▪ the withdrawal of the allied forces is now a strong possibility.
be a strong possibility (that)
có khả năng rằng
▪ there is a strong possibility that both the murders were committed by one man.
be a strong possibility of
có khả năng
▪ the weather forecast says that there’s a strong possibility of snow.

children.name: i should think
children.definition: british /i would think/guessamerican /ˌaɪ ʃʌd ˈθɪŋk, ˌaɪ wʊd ˈθɪŋk, ˈges/ spoken say this when you know enough about a situation to think something is likely to be true or likely to happen:tôi đoán
examples: ▪ the garden’s about 100 metres long, i would guess.
i should think (that)
▪ i should think she’s about 24 or 25.
▪ i would think that almost everyone could get here on a saturday.
i should/would think so
▪ ‘will the match still go ahead?’ ‘yes, i should think so.’

children.name: be on the cards c2
children.definition: be on the cardsbritish /be in the cardsamerican /biː ɒn ðə ˈkɑːʳdz, biː ɪn ðə ˈkɑːʳdz/  use this to say that something is likely to happen because of the present situation:có thể xảy ra
examples: ▪ they say that another recession is on the cards.
▪ no one was surprised when they got a divorce. it had been on the cards for years
.▪ i was hoping for a promotion, but it doesn’t seem to be in the cards right now.

children.name: may well b2
children.definition: may/could/might well/meɪ, kʊd, maɪt ˈwel/  if something may well happen or may well be true, it is fairly likely to happen or to be true: có lẽ đúng
examples: ▪ take an umbrella. it might well rain later on.
▪ that’s only my opinion. i could well be wrong.
▪ the eruption of santorini in 1470 bc may well have been heard as far away as britain.
it may well be (that)
▪ it could well be that it is too late for us to reverse the effects of global warming.
sth may well be the case
▪ ‘apparently, interest rates could rise again next month.’ ‘yes, that might well be the case.’

children.name: how likely it is that sth will happen
likelihood c2
children.definition: likelihood
examples: likelihood of
▪ as you get older, the likelihood of illness increases.
▪ studies have shown that there is a greater likelihood of teenagers having car accidents.
likelihood (that)
▪ there is little likelihood that the number of college places will go up this year.

children.name: chances b1
children.definition: chances/ˈtʃɑːnsɪz, ˈtʃɑːnsəzǁˈtʃæn-/  how likely it is that somethingyou hope for will actually happen:
examples: khả năng có thể
chances of (doing) something
khả năng có thể làm cái gì đó
▪ the new treatment will increase her chances of survival.
▪ for these men the chances of getting another job are not very high.
what are the chances...? : khả năng nhiều hay ít như thế nào
▪ what are the chances of that happening twice in one month?
chances are (that)... it is likely that : có thể rằng
▪ if you eat a balanced, low-fat diet, chances are your arteries will be healthy.

children.name: probability c1
children.definition: probability/ˌprɒbəˈbɪlɪti, ˌprɒbəˈbɪlətiǁˌprɑː-/  how likely it is that something will happen - use this especially about situations where you can calculate fairly exactly how likely something is:
examples: khả năng có thể xảy ra
probability of
khả năng có thể xảy ra của
▪ the probability of catching the disease from your partner is extremely low.
▪ we must increase our efforts to reduce the probability of such an accident happening again.
probability (that)
khả năng có thể xảy ra rằng
▪ there is a 90% probability that the hurricane will hit the coast of florida later today.
a strong probability
khả năng cao
▪ there is a strong probability that the problem will recur if we do not deal with it now.

children.name: prospect b2
children.definition: prospect/ˈprɒspektǁˈprɑː-/  the chance that something you hope for will happen soon:triển vọng
examples: prospect for
triển vọng đối với
▪ the prospects for peace are improving.
no/little prospect of (doing) something
không có/íttriển vọng làm cái gì đó
▪ he had no job and no prospect of getting one.
there is every prospect of somethingit is very likely
rất ít triển vọng về cái gì đó
▪ there is every prospect of an economic recovery next year.

children.name: odds c1
children.definition: odds/ɒdzǁɑːdz/  how likely it is that something will happen, especially when this can be stated in numbers:tỷ lệ
examples: odds in favour of
tỷ lệ nghiêng về
▪ the odds in favour of a win for the russian team are around 10 to 1.
odds of
tỷ lệ
▪ if you are male, the odds are about 1 in 12 of being colourblind.
odds against
tỷ lệ đối với
▪ the odds against being killed in a plane crash are very high.

children.name: very likely to happen or be true
very likely
children.definition: /more than likely/ˌveri ˈlaɪkli, ˌmɔːʳ ðən ˈlaɪkli/ rất có thể
examples: ▪ an early end to the dispute is now very likely.
▪ ‘do you think she’s still in love with him?’ ‘more than likely.’
▪ victory for the german team now seems more than likely.
very likely/more than likely to do something
rất có thể làm cái gì đó
▪ snow is very likely to spread across the region by the afternoon.
it’s very likely (that)
rất có thể rằng
▪ it’s very likely that he’ll be late -- he usually is.
very likely[adverb]rất có thể
▪ if you want a job done quickly, you’ll very likely have to do it yourself.

children.name: very probably
children.definition: /ˌveri ˈprɒbəbliǁ-ˈprɑː-/  especially written:rất có thể
examples: ▪ the number of dead will very probably reach 2,000 by the end of the day.
▪ the disease is very probably transmitted in water.

children.name: almost certain
children.definition: /ˌɔːlməʊst ˈsɜːʳtn/  extremely likely to happen or be true:hầu như chắc chắn
examples: it is almost certain (that)
hầu như chắc chắn rằng
▪ it is almost certain that the government will lose the next election.
almost certain to do something
hầu như chắc chắn làm cái gì đó
▪ bartholomew’s family is almost certain to appeal the court’s decision.
almost certainly[adverb]hầu như chắc chắn
▪ if you don’t follow the instructions, it’ll almost certainly go wrong.

children.name: in all probability c2
children.definition: in all probability /ɪn ˌɔːl prɒbəˈbɪltiǁ-prɑː-/  very probably - use this when you have considered something and you are giving your opinion about it:rất có khả năng
examples: ▪ in all probability, parts of the church date from even earlier than the twelfth century.
▪ she knew that, in all probability, he was seeing other women as well as herself.

children.name: ten to one x
children.definition: ten to one/ˌten tə ˈwʌn/  spoken say this when you think it is extremely likely that something will happen or has happened:cược một ăn mười, rất có thể
examples: (it’s)ten to one (that)
cược một ăn mười, rất có thể rằng
▪ stop worrying, mum. ten to one liz has just gone round to a friend’s house.
▪ it’s ten to one you’ll get the job - you’re perfect for it.

children.name: when sth will probably be good
should be b1
children.definition: ought to be/should be/ˈɔːt tə biː, ˈʃʊd biː/  use this to say that you think something or someone will probably be good, because of what you know about them:nên
examples: ▪ the party should be fun. there’s going to be a group playing and there’s lots of drink.
▪ she has all the right experience, so she ought to make an excellent manager.

children.name: promise to be b2
children.definition: promise to be/ˈprɒmɪs tə biː, ˈprɒməs tə biːǁˈprɑː-/  especially written if something that has just startedpromises to begood,exciting etc, it is very likely to be good, exciting etc:hứa hẹn là
examples: ▪ the day promised to be bright and warm.
▪ for those lucky enough to have tickets to the sold-out event, it promises to be a great evening of music.
promise to be good/exciting, etc. có vẻ…
to be expected to be good/exciting, etc
_it promises to be a really exciting match.

children.name: when sth bad is likely to happen
be heading for b2
children.definition: be heading for/biː ˈhedɪŋ fɔːʳ/  if someone is heading for an unpleasant situation, it is becoming more and more likely that this situation will actually happen:sắp phải
examples: ▪ i’m worried about molly. she looks as if she’s heading for a nervous breakdown.
▪ there are fears that the company could be heading for closure, following a bad year.

children.name: be in for c2
children.definition: be in for/biː ˈɪn fɔːʳ/  if you say you are in for something unpleasant, it is almost certain to happen to you fairly soon:sẽ bị
examples: ▪ it’s pretty stormy! i think we’re in for a rough flight.
▪ if they think they’re going to build a new motorway near here, they’re in for a shock.

children.name: threaten c2
children.definition: threaten if sth threatens to cause an unpleasant situation, it seems likely that it will cause it: đe dọa (nghĩa bóng)
examples: threaten to do sth
▪ the dispute threatened to damage east-west relations.
▪ somalia was again crippled by a drought that threatened to kill hundreds of thousands more.
threaten sb/sth with sth
▪ our rainforests are being threatened with destruction, and the consequences will be severe.

children.name: threat b2
children.definition: threat /θret/  something that is a threat is likely to cause something unpleasant to happen: sự đe dọa
examples: threat of
▪ the threat of inflation and high interest rates led to a wage freeze.
▪ the threat of invasionthreat to
▪ after the floods, contaminated water was a serious threat to public health.
pose a threat (for)
▪ global warming poses a serious threat for the future.

children.name: to be likely to do sth surprising or bad
be quite capable of
children.definition: use this when you think that sb is fairly likely to do sth bad or surprising, because of what you know about their character: khá có khả năng
examples: ▪ she promised to come, but she’s quite capable of forgetting.
▪ don’t believe it! he’s quite capable of lying!

children.name: not put it past sb x
children.definition: i wouldn’t put it past somebody/aɪ ˌwʊdnt pʊt ɪt ˈpɑːst somebody ǁ-ˈpæst-/ informal use this to say that you think a particular person is fairly likely to do the bad or stupid thing that you are mentioning:tôi không lấy làm lạ là ai đó
examples: ▪ ‘she wouldn’t have read my e-mail, would she?’ ‘well, i wouldn’t put it past her.’
i wouldn’t put it past sb to do something
tôi không lấy làm lạ là ai đó làm cái gì đó
▪ i wouldn’t put it past kevin to have borrowed the car without asking.

children.name: to be likely to be successful
good chance b1
children.definition: have/stand a good chance có khả năng cao
examples: ▪ ‘do you think he’ll get the job?’ ‘well, he certainly has a very good chance.’
have/stand a good chance of doing sth
▪ i think bart’s design stands a really good chance of winning the competition.

children.name: be set to do sth u
children.definition: be set to do something /biː ˌset tə ˈduː/  to be very likely to be successful because of being well prepared or because the present situation is favourable: được định sẵn để làm cái gì đó
examples: ▪ the band’s new album is set to become the biggest hit of the year.
look set to do sth
▪ shares in the company look set to soar.

children.name: on course x
children.definition: be on course/biː ɒn ˈkɔːʳs/  to be likely to achieve something because there has already been some success:rất có khả năng
examples: be on course for
rất có khả năng
▪ the business is on course for record profits this year.
be on course to do something
rất có khả năng làm cái gì đó
▪ after three major victories, the brazilian team seemed on course to win the cup.

children.name: chances are c2
children.definition: (the) chances areinformal
examples: it is likely
_chances are(that)they'll be late anyway.

children.name: as likely b1
children.definition: as likely/like as not
examples: probably
_as likely as not, she'll end up in court over this problem.
